pullRequest.body:
This parses the `lake-manifest` to work out where mathlib is.

Previously this assumed it was in `.lake/packages`, but this is only true of `git` packages. As a result, it would fail with:
```
uncaught exception: no such file or directory (error code: 2)
  file: .lake/packages/mathlib/lakefile.lean
```

Tested on a blank project created with `lake new test math`, with `require mathlib from "../mathlib4"` in the lakefile.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

nodes.body:
Sorry, it's been a while since I've got in touch with this code so my review is definitely unsatisfactory.
But let me ask: is `lake-manifest.json` guaranteed to always be present when using this or will there be some egg-chicken problem?
In my memory, I wanted to do something like this. But for some reason, my plan of action was to parse the `lakefile.lean` directly.
`lake-manifest` should always be checked in next to the lakefile.

> `lake-manifest` should always be checked in next to the lakefile.

Is it there when you first create a project?

> > `lake-manifest` should always be checked in next to the lakefile.
> 
> Is it there when you first create a project?

No, sadly, it is not.
bors d+

:v: eric-wieser can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7012190458/job/19076236327)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7012190458/job/19076237051)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7012190458/job/19076236699)

```suggestion
  | .error e => throw $ IO.userError s!"Cannot parse lake-manifest.json: {e}"
```

```suggestion
      pure (( mathlibDepPath) / )
```

```suggestion
    let mathlibDepPath := ( mathlibDepPath).toString
```

Add a `try / catch` here, and a helpful error message about what to do about a missing `lake-manifest.json`.

Perhaps:
"If this is a new project, you will need to run `lake build` first in order for construct your initial `lake-manifest.json`. If this is an existing project, contact the authors to ask that they include the `lake-manifest.json` file."
(We just had someone on zulip asking if they should .gitignore their lake-manifest.json... So people are going to do it!)

The act of running `lake exe cache get` (presumably `lake exe` anything) appears to create the manifest file; so I think this is basically unreachable, and the help text you suggest is unlikely to help anyone reaching it.

I confirmed that `lake exe nonexistant` also creates `lake-manifest.json`, even if we disable the post-update hook in Mathlib; so I think this is not anything to worry about.

(Weirdly, if the manifest is missing, `lake exe nonexistant` also runs `lake exe get cache`, because of the post-update hook!)
Great!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - fix(Cache): correctly handle local copies of `Mathlib`
